ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

ElementDescription: Sex of subject at birth
Notes: M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

ElementDescription: Case/Control - This classifies Probands as Cases, Controls as Controls, and Family Members as either Affected or Unaffected based on DIPAD responses and/or diagnoses.
Notes: 1= Case; 2= Control; 3= Affected Family Member; 4= Unaffected Family Member

ElementDescription: Type of subject
Type of control
Notes: 1= Diabetes; 2= Coronary Artery Disease; 3= Breast Cancer; 4= Osteoporosis Arthritis

ElementDescription: Have you ever taken part in a genetics study?
Site Name - This is the institution or geographical location where subjects for the given site ID are being collected. A Site Name can have more than one Site ID.

Site Country - This is the country in which the site ID is located. Most site IDs are associated with one country; for those few that are associated with more than one, we figure out the subject's Site Country by the Collection Point field.
Site State - For USA sites, this is the state in which the site ID is located. This includes site IDs associated with more than one country, so long as one of those countries is the USA.

Collection - This is the broad category of records that this subject falls into, such as the set of all records for a particular funded study. It is useful for tracking enrollment. (In Progeny we called this the 'STUDY' field.) It is based primarily on the site ID, and secondarily (when a site ID belongs to more than one collection) the enrollment date. There is also some special handling of subjects in the COVID collection, which are reassigned to the PUMAS or AAGPC2 collections according to whether or not they are GPC-consented.
Zip3 - This 3-digit zip code prefix is useful when exporting data. Per HIPAA, the full zip code is protected health information, but the first 3 digits may be exported as de-identified data.
Referral Type - How was the subject recruited?
Notes: 1= Advertising; 2= Board and Care; 3= Community Event; 4= Inpatient; 5= Inpatient - Substance Tx; 6= MA: Outpatient; 7= Outpatient Clinic; 8= Self; 9= Unknown; 10= USC Outpatient; 11= USC Outpatient Clinic; 12= Ward Off Letter; 13= COVID Biobank

ElementDescription: Family ID - This is just the Subject ID without any family member suffix. All subjects in the same family share the same family_id.
Mother ID - If we have a record for the subject's mother, this is her Subject ID.
Father ID - If we have a record for the subject's father, this is his Subject ID.

Ethnicity - Any other notes for this section:

1. Have you ever had a time that lasted 3 days or more when you felt unusually cheerful, irritable, energetic, or hyperactive? So much that you felt or acted in a way that was clearly different from your normal self?

1. Has anyone in your family ever had a time that lasted 3 days or more when they felt unusually cheerful, irritable, energetic, or hyperactive? So much that they felt or acted in a way that was clearly different from your normal self?
2. Have you ever had a time that lasted 3 days or more when you needed much less sleep than usual (or no sleep at all) without feeling tired, or even feeling more energetic than usual?

2. Has anyone in your family ever had a time that lasted 3 days or more when they needed much less sleep than usual (or no sleep at all) without feeling tired, or even feeling more energetic than usual?

3. During the same time (either gpc_scr01 or gpc_scr02), did you talk much more than usual, take on many more activities or tasks than usual, or do things that might have gotten you in trouble -- things that you would not normally do? Examples: sexual overactivity, unrestrained spending sprees, foolish investments, and other risky or reckless behaviors.

3. During the same time (either gpc_scr01 or gpc_scr02), did anyone in your family talk much more than usual, take on many more activities or tasks than usual, or do things that might have gotten them in trouble -- things that they would not normally do? Examples: sexual overactivity, unrestrained spending sprees, foolish investments, and other risky or reckless behaviors.
4. Have you ever been diagnosed with manic-depressive illness (bipolar disorder)?
4. Has anyone in your family ever been diagnosed with manic-depressive illness (bipolar disorder)?
5. Have you received psychiatric medication or other psychiatric treatment for any problem listed in questions gpc_scr01-04?
5. Has anyone in your family received psychiatric medication or other psychiatric treatment for any problem listed in questions gpc_scr01-04?
6. Have you ever had a time when you heard voices when no one was actually present, had visions, or saw things that other people could not see?
6. Has anyone in your family ever had a time when they heard voices when no one was actually present, had visions, or saw things that other people could not see?

7. Did you ever have beliefs or ideas that others did not share or you later found out were not true? Examples: people trying to harm you, something outside you was controlling your thoughts, thinking had unique or extraordinary powers, or believing that the TV or radio was giving you special messages.

7. Did anyone in your family ever have beliefs or ideas that others did not share or they later found out were not true? Examples: people trying to harm them, something outside them was controlling their thoughts, thinking they had unique or extraordinary powers, or believing that the TV or radio was giving them special messages.

8. Have you ever had your body stuck in one position so that you couldn't move, acted in ways that other people thought were very odd or inappropriate, or said things that didn't make any sense to other people?

8. Has anyone in your family ever had your body stuck in one position so that they couldn't move, acted in ways that other people thought were very odd or inappropriate, or said things that didn't make any sense to other people?
9. Have you ever been diagnosed with schizophrenia?
9. Has anyone in your family ever been diagnosed with schizophrenia?
10. Have you received psychiatric medication or other psychiatric treatment for any problem listed in questions gpc_scr06-09?
10. Has anyone in your family received psychiatric medication or other psychiatric treatment for any problem listed in questions gpc_scr06-09?
P11. Was there a period of at least half a year when you have been continually worried or anxious about a number of events or activities in your daily life?
P11a. Did you worry excessively or uncontrollably about minor things such as being late for an appointment, minor repairs, homework, etc.?
P11b. Was your worry excessive in intensity, frequency, or amount of distress it causes?
P11c. Did you find it difficult to control the worry (or stop worrying) once it starts?
P12. Have you ever been diagnosed with Anxiety?
P12a.What type of anxiety were you diagnosed with?
Notes: 1= Generalized Anxiety Disorder; 3= Panic Disorder; 5= Social Phobia (or Social Anxiety Disorder); 6= Specific Phobias (e.g. intense fear of spiders, height, flying); 7= Agoraphobia; 8= Separation Anxiety; 9= Selective Mutism; 10= Medication-Induced Anxiety Disorder; 11= Any other type of anxiety [anxiety_diagn_type_specify]

ElementDescription: Diagnosed with any other type of anxiety, please, specify

11. Did you ever have an experience of suddenly feeling very anxious or fearful and having panic-like physical symptoms that developed and got intense within 10 minutes? Examples: racing heart, chest pain, choking feelings, nausea, sweating, faint, thinking you were going crazy, or dying.

11a. Have you had more than one attack like this: and had a period lasting at least 1 month of intense worries about having another attack or changed your behaviors for at least 1 month because of the attacks?
P23. Have you ever used alcohol in your life?
12. Do you often have more than 4 drinks in one day (for women) or more than 5 drinks in one day (for men)?

13. Have you been under the influence of alcohol 3 or more times in situations where you could have caused an accident or gotten hurt? Examples: driving while intoxicated, operating machinery, during sports, or while using a gun.
14. Have you often had a lot more to drink than you intended to have or do you often drink to calm your nerves?
15. Have you ever wanted to quit or tried to cut down on your drinking and found that you couldn't?
16. Have people annoyed you by criticizing your drinking?
17. Have you ever had a drink first thing in the morning to steady your nerves or get rid of a hangover [eye-opener]?
P23h. Do you currently use alcohol?
18. Over your lifetime, have you smoked more than 100 cigarettes? Include cigars, pipes, chewing tobacco, and electronic cigarettes.
19. Have you ever had a period of one month or more when you smoked cigarettes every day?
20. Did you usually smoke your first cigarette within one hour after waking up?
21. Have you ever wanted to quit smoking or have tried to quit smoking and found that you couldn't?
22. Have you ever felt depressed, down, sad, or blue for most of the day, nearly every day for 2 weeks or more?
22. Has anyone in your family ever felt depressed, down, sad, or blue for most of the day, nearly every day for 2 weeks or more?

23. Did you ever have a period of 2 weeks or more when you lost most or all interest in your normal activities? Examples: working at your job, spending time with family or friends, enjoying your hobbies or interests, exercising or taking a walk.

23. Did anyone in your family ever have a period of 2 weeks or more when they lost most or all interest in their normal activities? Examples: working at their job, spending time with family or friends, enjoying their hobbies or interests, exercising or taking a walk.

24. During that same time (either gpc_scr22 or 23), did you also have feelings of worthlessness, or feel too much guilt, or spend a lot of time thinking about death or dying, or have thoughts about hurting or killing yourself?

24. During that same time (either gpc_scr22 or 23), did anyone in your family also have feelings of worthlessness, or feel too much guilt, or spend a lot of time thinking about death or dying, or have thoughts about hurting or killing themselves?

25. During that same time (either gpc_scr22 or 23), did you experience a significant change in your appetite, have unplanned weight gain or loss, experience changes in your normal sleep pattern, or have difficulties concentrating?

25. During that same time (either gpc_scr22 or 23), did anyone in your family experience a significant change in their appetite, have unplanned weight gain or loss, experience changes in their normal sleep pattern, or have difficulties concentrating?
25a. Have you received psychiatric medication or other psychiatric treatment for any problem listed in questions gpc_scr22-25?
25a. Has anyone in your family received psychiatric medication or other psychiatric treatment for any problem listed in questions gpc_scr22-25?
25b. Number of times you have experienced the things described in questions gpc_scr22-25? [scr25b_pak_desc]
Notes: -1= Data Not Collected; -2= Too Many To Count

32. Have you ever experienced a traumatic event in which you felt that your life might be in danger? Examples: serious car or other accident, natural disaster (like earthquakes or hurricanes), being physically attacked or threatened with a knife or gun, being sexually assaulted or raped, experienced combat or been in a war zone, or observed sudden violent death (homicide or suicide.)

32a. Experienced traumatic event in which you felt that your life might be in danger - Sometimes images or strong memories of traumatic events keep coming back in flashbacks, thoughts that you can't get rid of, or repeated nightmares. Has that ever happened to you?

32b. Experienced traumatic event in which you felt that your life might be in danger - Did you make a special effort to avoid thinking or talking about what happened or deliberately stayed away from things or people that reminded you of the terrible experience?

32c. Experienced traumatic event in which you felt that your life might be in danger - After this experience did you have trouble sleeping, have difficulty concentrating, were unusually irritable, have outbursts of anger, felt overly watchful or on guard, or been very jumpy or easily startled?
